fields.title: The First Bonus Dilemma
fields.description: You just received a surprise Diwali bonus of ₹50,000! This is your first big lump sum. How you handle this defines your financial year. Do you treat yourself, play it safe, or grow it?

fields.title: The Laptop Crash
fields.description: Your laptop just died, and you need it for freelance work. It costs ₹40,000 to replace. You don’t have an emergency fund yet. How do you pay for it?

fields.title: Market Panic!
fields.description: The stock market just crashed by 20% due to global news. Your portfolio value is dropping fast. What do you do?

fields.title: The Minimum Due Trap
fields.description: you have a credit card bill of ₹25,000. You have exactly ₹25,000 in your bank account. The "Minimum Due" is only ₹2,000.

fields.why_it_matters: Investing early lets compound interest work its magic. Even small amounts grow huge over 10 years.
fields.mentor_feedback: Excellent. 12% compounding is how wealth is built.

fields.why_it_matters: FDs are great for emergency funds, but tax and inflation eat up most of your real returns.
fields.mentor_feedback: Safe choice. You beat inflation, but barely

fields.why_it_matters: Depreciating assets (like gadgets) make you poorer over time. Assets put money IN your pocket.
fields.mentor_feedback: Ouch. That phone loses 20% value the moment you open the box.

fields.why_it_matters: Credit card debt usually charges 18-36% interest, destroying wealth.
fields.mentor_feedback: High interest eats your future income.

fields.why_it_matters: Buying used depreciating assets saves capital for appreciating investments.
Don't spend 100% of your liquidity on a single depreciating asset.
fields.mentor_feedback: Overkill. You wiped out your cash.

fields.why_it_matters: Buying low lowers your average cost, leading to massive gains when markets recover.
fields.mentor_feedback: Be greedy when others are fearful

fields.why_it_matters: Inactivity is often the best activity in investing. Never interrupt compounding.
Panic selling turns a temporary market dip into a permanent loss of wealth.
fields.mentor_feedback: You just locked in a permanent loss

fields.why_it_matters: Never invest if you have high-interest debt (30%) vs market returns (12%).
fields.mentor_feedback: Bad math. Card interest > Investment return.

fields.why_it_matters: Clearing high-interest debt provides a guaranteed "return" equal to the interest rate saved.
Paying only minimum due keeps you in debt for years due to compound interest against you.
fields.mentor_feedback: The trap is set. Interest will pile up
